body:
@HishamSalem, the `TransformedTargetForecaster` does implement prediction intervals currently! For that, the forecaster in it needs to support prediction intervals.

If you want to *add* prediction intervals to a forecaster that doesnÂ´t natively have them, you can use one of the wrappers that add them to any forecaster, like `NaiveVariance` or `ConvormalIntervals`.

@fkiraly  Thank you for the advice, I tried this and it still gives a not implemented error. 

Code:

from sktime.datasets import load_airline
from sktime.forecasting.naive import NaiveVariance
from sktime.forecasting.compose import TransformedTargetForecaster,make_reduction #Make reduction
from xgboost import XGBRegressor

y = load_airline()
forecaster = TransformedTargetForecaster(
    [        
      (
          "forecast",
          make_reduction(XGBRegressor()   
              ,
              scitype="tabular-regressor",
              window_length=16,
              strategy="recursive",),
      ),
  ])
#forecast
variance_forecaster = NaiveVariance(forecaster)
variance_forecaster.fit(y)
var_pred = variance_forecaster.predict_interval(fh=[1,2,3],coverage=0.9)



NotImplementedError: Generating in-sample predictions is not yet implemented for RecursiveTabularRegressionForecaster.

But that error has nothing to do with prediction intervals.
I think it is the reduction forecaster which is asked by the reduction to make forecasts for in-sample values, when you use it inside `NaiveVariance`.
It may or may not have to do with overlapping train/test sets as @bethrice44 had pointed out, but what you pasted here is not a problem with prediction intervals but a restriction of the reduction forecaster.

Have you tried `ConformalIntervals`, that is another option to get the probabilistic intervals?

I do not think the ConformalIntervals is in my modules yet. Do I need to update sktime? 

I did try to take the module directly into my pc, can you share the installation wheel so that I can import ConformalIntervals?
ah, that's not in 0.11.4 yet but will be in the 0.12.0 release in the next days. Sorry for the confusion.

bootstrap bagging is in the works here, btw:
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2248

I updated the package as instructed and I do get an indexing error specifically for sliding window models. The error mainly has to do with the make reduction package. 

from sktime.datasets import load_airline
from sktime.forecasting.conformal import ConformalIntervals
from sktime.forecasting.naive import NaiveForecaster
y = load_airline()
forecaster = TransformedTargetForecaster(
    [        
      (
          "forecast",
          make_reduction(XGBRegressor()   
              ,
              scitype="tabular-regressor",
              window_length=16,
              strategy="recursive",),
      ),
  ])
Variance=NaiveVariance(forecaster)
conformal_forecaster = ConformalIntervals(Variance)
conformal_forecaster.fit(y, fh=[1,2,3])
pred_int = conformal_forecaster.predict_interval()


[<ipython-input-33-5c283e44b7db>](https://localhost:8080/#) in <module>()
     16 Variance=NaiveVariance(forecaster)
     17 conformal_forecaster = ConformalIntervals(Variance)
---> 18 conformal_forecaster.fit(y, fh=[1,2,3])
     19 pred_int = conformal_forecaster.predict_interval()

8 frames
[/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/pandas/core/indexing.py](https://localhost:8080/#) in _align_frame(self, indexer, df)
   2199             return val
   2200 
-> 2201         raise ValueError("Incompatible indexer with DataFrame")
   2202 
   2203 

ValueError: Incompatible indexer with DataFrame

@HishamSalem, content-wise, you should not be wrapping a forecaster in *two* of the interval generating wrappers - use at most one.

In theory, though, it should still work if you wrap them in both. @bethrice44, any idea what is happening?

This very similar code works (I used `RandomForest` instead of `XGBRegressor` to stay inside `sktime` dependency set)

```python

from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor

from sktime.datasets import load_airline
from sktime.forecasting.compose import make_reduction
from sktime.forecasting.conformal import ConformalIntervals
from sktime.forecasting.naive import NaiveForecaster

y = load_airline()

f = make_reduction(
    RandomForestRegressor(),
    scitype="tabular-regressor",
    window_length=16,
    strategy="recursive",
)

conformal_forecaster = ConformalIntervals(f)
conformal_forecaster.fit(y, fh=[1,2,3])
pred_int = conformal_forecaster.predict_interval()
```

Hm, the same code fails when wrapped in `TransformedTargetForecaster`:

```python
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor

from sktime.datasets import load_airline
from sktime.forecasting.compose import make_reduction,TransformedTargetForecaster
from sktime.forecasting.conformal import ConformalIntervals
from sktime.forecasting.naive import NaiveForecaster

y = load_airline()

forecaster = TransformedTargetForecaster(
    [(
        "forecast",
        make_reduction(
            RandomForestRegressor(),
            scitype="tabular-regressor",
            window_length=16,
            strategy="recursive",
        ),
    )]
)

conformal_forecaster = ConformalIntervals(forecaster)
conformal_forecaster.fit(y, fh=[1,2,3])
pred_int = conformal_forecaster.predict_interval()
```

Seems to be an interaction between `ConvormalIntervals` and `TransformedTargetForecaster`. Any ideas, @bethrice44?

This does not work either, i.e., it does not matter what is wrapped within the `TransformedTargetForecaster`.

```python
from sktime.datasets import load_airline
from sktime.forecasting.arima import ARIMA
from sktime.forecasting.compose import TransformedTargetForecaster
from sktime.forecasting.conformal import ConformalIntervals

y = load_airline()

forecaster = TransformedTargetForecaster(
    [(
        "forecast",
        ARIMA(),
    )]
)

conformal_forecaster = ConformalIntervals(forecaster)
conformal_forecaster.fit(y, fh=[1,2,3])
pred_int = conformal_forecaster.predict_interval()
```

or this 

```python
from sktime.datasets import load_airline
from sktime.forecasting.naive import NaiveForecaster
from sktime.forecasting.compose import TransformedTargetForecaster
from sktime.forecasting.conformal import ConformalIntervals

y = load_airline()

forecaster = TransformedTargetForecaster(
    [(
        "forecast",
        NaiveForecaster(),
    )]
)

conformal_forecaster = ConformalIntervals(forecaster)
conformal_forecaster.fit(y, fh=[1,2,3])
pred_int = conformal_forecaster.predict_interval()
```

@fkiraly That makes sense, thanks for the clarification. I think problem is associated with pipeline might be the problem because it does work when using the just the sklearn model as is however when integrating make_pipeline as well the same error pops up.  

Sample:
```
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor

from sktime.datasets import load_airline
from sktime.forecasting.compose import make_reduction,TransformedTargetForecaster
from sktime.forecasting.conformal import ConformalIntervals
from sktime.forecasting.naive import NaiveForecaster

y = load_airline()

forecaster = make_pipeline(
    Deseasonalizer(),    
    make_reduction(RandomForestRegressor(), window_length=12, strategy="recursive"),
)

conformal_forecaster = ConformalIntervals(forecaster)
conformal_forecaster.fit(y, fh=[1,2,3])
pred_int = conformal_forecaster.predict_interval()
```
However when we avoid pipelineing
```
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor

from sktime.datasets import load_airline
from sktime.forecasting.compose import make_reduction,TransformedTargetForecaster
from sktime.forecasting.conformal import ConformalIntervals
from sktime.forecasting.naive import NaiveForecaster

y = load_airline()

forecaster = make_reduction(RandomForestRegressor(), window_length=52, strategy="recursive")

conformal_forecaster = ConformalIntervals(forecaster)
conformal_forecaster.fit(y, fh=[1,2,3])
pred_int = conformal_forecaster.predict_interval()
```

yes - on slack, @bethrice44 has posted a suspicion what this could be.

ItÂ´s possibly `ConvormalInterval` copying the `y_inner_mtype` argument over from the wrapped model, which controls internal data type conversions. Perhaps it should convert to a specific type instead, with which the interval computations are compatible.
